channel.title: Which Linux should I get?
channel.description: Anyways, I have a Dell laptop (Inspiron 1300) in my house and we gave it to my sister as her own computer. However, its pretty much crap, and runs slow as shit. So, instead of trying to fix it, I decided to put a Linux distro on it, which is why I'm posting this. Which distro so I put on the computer? I'm already leaning towards Ubuntu because its widely used, but I'd like to know if there is one more suitable for a 12-year old :P Any advice is appreciated.

item.title: Which Linux should I get?
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“pure2ownage, post:38, topic:354601”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=451168.msg3315049#msg3315049 date=1282253548]

[quote author=CoonHunter link=topic=451168.msg3310937#msg3310937 date=1281982488]

Thanks. I’ll do that

I will get on MSN if you need further help, trying to make Win3.1 more advanced (dual booting it atm with win7?)
[/quote]Yeah, I’m Dual-Booting with Win7.

Here is a pic of it, so you understand what OS this is:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_3.1x

That is absolutely NOT Windows 3.1, because 3.1 didn’t have a bar at the bottom, a start menu, or a desktop, I know because my first computer had 3.1 on it when it was cutting-edge technology. That looks more like Windows 95.
[/quote]The GUI on the apps seems like a very old Mac but it looks more like 95/98 then 3.1[/quote]
Windows 95/98 don’t say “Calmira II” on them. I can give you bootable disk images of 3.1, 95, and 98 to run via DOSBOX if you wanted. Its a fairly large file for all of them though.

Read full topic

item.title: Which Linux should I get?
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[quote=“rip4d, post:26, topic:354601”][quote author=HcoJustin link=topic=451168.msg3310442#msg3310442 date=1281934121]
Wine typically install’s its “C” drive in ~/.wine/, but like MITB said, there isn’t a reason to use wine for a wireless driver. Have you checked online for better fixes?

Quickly searching the model you’ve given, I found this… http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1387483
[/quote]I’ve tried using the original guide but it wouldn’t work for me because I’d get something such as “access denied” or “directory not found” I think its because its meant for Ubuntu 9.10.[/quote]

Post some specifics. Access denied is usually from not having root access, and the directory isn’t found because you either typed it wrong, or it didn’t exist… If there were any problems people would have notified the OP and he should have updated the post…

Read full topic

Here is a pic of it, so you understand what OS this is:

en.wikipedia.org

Windows 3.1x

Windows 3.1x (codenamed Janus) is a series of 16-bit operating environments produced by Microsoft for use on personal computers. The series began with Windows 3.1, which was first sold during April 1992 as a successor to Windows 3.0. Subsequent versions were released between 1992 and 1994 until the series was superseded by Windows 95. During its lifespan, Windows 3.1 introduced several enhancements to the still MS-DOS-based platform, including improved system stability, expanded support Windows ...

item.title: Which Linux should I get?
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“rip4d, post:26, topic:354601”][quote author=HcoJustin link=topic=451168.msg3310442#msg3310442 date=1281934121]
Wine typically install’s its “C” drive in ~/.wine/, but like MITB said, there isn’t a reason to use wine for a wireless driver. Have you checked online for better fixes?

Quickly searching the model you’ve given, I found this… http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1387483
[/quote]I’ve tried using the original guide but it wouldn’t work for me because I’d get something such as “access denied” or “directory not found” I think its because its meant for Ubuntu 9.10.[/quote]
If you get on the shell prompt and type:
“sudo apt-get install Wine1.2”
You should get an error if you are not connected, read the error and you will find the direct link to the correct install package

Read full topic

item.title: Which Linux should I get?
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:22, topic:354601”]If you have any ‘drives’ you aren’t in Linux. To answer the original question, I’d suggest Ubuntu or Kubuntu for you to start off with, it generally installs things like wireless drivers for you automatically.

Also, running a wireless driver .exe with WINE will get you nowhere, there is never a reason to do so.[/quote]
There sometimes is a reason, that is the only way I could get my old belkin wireless card to work, using NDISwrapper with the extracted .inf and .sys files for the driver never worked. It would successfully search for networks, but failed to connect. Running the .exe via WINE, got it to work flawlessly.

Read full topic

item.title: Which Linux should I get?
item.dc:creator: @rip4d rip4d
item.description:
@rip4d wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:22, topic:354601”]If you have any ‘drives’ you aren’t in Linux. To answer the original question, I’d suggest Ubuntu or Kubuntu for you to start off with, it generally installs things like wireless drivers for you automatically.

Also, running a wireless driver .exe with WINE will get you nowhere, there is never a reason to do so.[/quote]Well I am now using Ubuntu Lucid Lynx 10.04. The only reason I’m using Wine for my driver is because I can’t extract the .exe, thus making it impossible to use ndiswrapper. I successfully installed the wireless driver on the laptop my sister is using with ndiswrapper, but that’s because I managed to find another driver online that could be extracted.

Btw, I’m using a Belkin N+ USB wireless adapter, model F5D8055.

Read full topic

item.title: Which Linux should I get?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

If you have any ‘drives’ you aren’t in Linux. To answer the original question, I’d suggest Ubuntu or Kubuntu for you to start off with, it generally installs things like wireless drivers for you automatically.

Also, running a wireless driver .exe with WINE will get you nowhere, there is never a reason to do so.

Read full topic

item.title: Which Linux should I get?
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

If you are loaded into Ubuntu, then you do not have C:/ Z:/ or any of the following, that is a Microsoft/Windows thing. Ubuntu mounts things into its own file-system, like “/mnt/sbd0” is typically my Windows partition in Ubuntu.

Read full topic

item.title: Which Linux should I get?
item.dc:creator: @rip4d rip4d
item.description:
@rip4d wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:19, topic:354601”][quote author=rip4d link=topic=451168.msg3310031#msg3310031 date=1281914169]
Emm…where would I install a wireless driver? Normally it would be in Program Files under C:, but Ubuntu uses Z: and different directories, and I’m not sure which one to install the driver to.
[/quote]
Run it under wine, and leave directories as the installer wants. Wine creates a virtual C:/ drive inside of Ubuntu.[/quote]But the C: Drive is my windows drive, Z: is for Ubuntu since I’m running them both on the same computer.

Read full topic

item.title: Which Linux should I get?
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

rip4d:

Emm…where would I install a wireless driver? Normally it would be in Program Files under C:, but Ubuntu uses Z: and different directories, and I’m not sure which one to install the driver to.

Run it under wine, and leave directories as the installer wants. Wine creates a virtual C:/ drive inside of Ubuntu.

Read full topic

[quote=“rip4d, post:16, topic:354601”][quote author=CoonHunter link=topic=451168.msg3309806#msg3309806 date=1281901897]
No, Wine is available via the DEB package on the Ubuntu website.

You can download it here and install it via shell.
http://packages.ubuntu.com/lucid/wine1.2
[/quote]Ah, thanks Coon :)[/quote]
If you would like any further help, MSN: kenshin1388@hotmail.com
